name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @KhanRoper Starting from late March in my research service, I've been pointing out a probable gold reversal to the upside, and recommending some gold stocks again.   So far we've gotten that, but we'll see if it has legs. It will likely depend on real yields and M2 growth.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @ttmygh @fleckcap In the 1940s, there were transitory inflation spikes, but in aggregate they resulted in permanently higher price levels each time, since the money supply had expanded so much.   In other words, transitory in rate of change terms, but sticky in absolute terms.  https://t.co/svlf1CcfU2

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @7rendline Then use your preferred metrics.  https://t.co/o6UnCr7pak

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @7rendline People that use gold vs m2 keep losing money over the long run and are surprised that gold isn't way higher, because it is the wrong metric.   Gold mining output is known with decent precision; enough to make the model way more useful by incorporating it.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @7rendline Comparing gold to M2 doesn't make much sense.   Need to compare either a) gold market cap to M2, or b) adjust M2 to make it per capita.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @Jan_Kuijlen @TweeterE @PeterSchiff Not sure what you're referring to. Gold is more than twice the price it was in 1980.   Also, gold was in a bubble in 1980.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @TweeterE @PeterSchiff No, it means that since the gold supply is relatively finite (~1.5% annual supply growth via mining), its price tends to grow over time so that the price keeps up with broad money supply growth.  Sometimes it gets way ahead of itself, and other times it lags, based on real rates.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Mainly what gold has done over the long run, is keep up with broad money supply growth.   It tends to overshoot the trend when real rates are negative, and undershoot the trend when real rates are positive.   Discussed at SF Online:  https://t.co/h3oAbDDczP  https://t.co/XoWgkOlBZR

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: In which I discuss bitcoin with Mike Green. Thanks to him for participating and IEX for reaching out with the idea and hosting:

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @HaniCrypto No, a scammer.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @Platinum_Gloves The overall situation of foreigners buying US assets with their trade surpluses is exponential, so in recent years the numbers became pretty big.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @resalerussell Japan's median age is ten years older which factors in as well.   Countries with similar obesity rates to the US and similar life expectancies, don't spend what we spend.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @electronicado86 A big reason why they have high personal savings is that they spend half as much on healthcare per capita as the US and less on military.  The US structured itself to have a structural trade deficit.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @B166ERcrypto The gain in corporate profits as a % of GDP was mainly due to lower corporate taxes. The valuations applied to those profits was mainly due to low rates and foreign investment.   Pre-tax corporate profits are in-line with the long-term trend:  https://t.co/wlStKmPiqt

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @electronicado86 -The US S&P 500 has a *smaller* percentage of their revenues coming from foreign markets than a decade ago.  -The specific labor offshoring trend has impacted the US more than similarly expensive countries (western Europe, Japan, etc).  There are some structural specifics.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: A lot of people like to singularly blame central banks (rates and QE) for wealth concentration since it's easy, but the problem runs a lot deeper and more structural than that.   It's more of a monetary structure, fiscal, trade, and geopolitical problem.  https://t.co/UN1xCkWZcW

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Many investors (US and non-US) don't see it, since we're the ones benefiting from it.   However, investors shouldn't be surprised by bouts of populism in the US and elsewhere. The system has been straining for a while now under its own design. Folks push back.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Americans pay the highest per-capita cost of healthcare in the world.   We also have a higher share of tax dollars spent on military than Europe/Japan, which mostly goes to defending this trade situation that benefits the wealthy over US workers.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: This structural trade situation is why, despite Europe and Japan having lower interest rates and more QE as a % of GDP than the US, their wealth concentration isn't as high as in the US.   A chart of mean vs median wealth. Numbers via Credit Suisse wealth report:  https://t.co/1SKaan30cU

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Lately this has expanded to the residential real estate market.   Foreigners now also reinvest their trade surplus dollars into buying US single family homes and renting them back to Americans, collecting income from them.   A good piece from the WSJ:   https://t.co/IFjWVGLjJy

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Since the top 1% own 53% of US equities, and the bottom 50% own less than 1% of US equities (and many of them had jobs/wages impacted by offshoring/automation), this trend of declining labor and increasing profits/valuations has favored wealth concentration.  https://t.co/nGh721D6sC

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: In addition to being partly due to technology/automation, another part of this is due to structural US trade deficits.   The US exported large portions of our supply chains overseas, and foreigners took those dollars and reinvested them back into US equities.  https://t.co/TOBRVjx7gm

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Over the past couple decades, US labor share of GDP has decreased to being well below trend (left chart), while US corporate profits as a percentage of GDP have increased to being above-trend (right chart).   A thread.  https://t.co/X9zAP232OQ

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @CyberSpaceGal This is the T-bill rate minus official inflation statistics.   So whenever the blue area is below zero, it means money in the bank or in short-duration Treasuries is losing purchasing power over time.   If actual inflation is higher than CPI, then more-so.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: The past decade has not been kind to cash-equivalents.  https://t.co/s8hcLJehBK

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @DeMonteCrypto Conditions look a lot more like the 1960s.   1920s had no FDIC insurance, banks failed, etc. 1960s had big fiscal programs, changing geopolitical landscape, etc.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @BTC_Archive 20s was credit bubble popping, no FDIC insurance, so banks going bust and destroying a third of M2.   60s was domestic fiscal programs + war, resulting in inflationary pressures, then geopolitical issues in the 1970s causing high oil prices. Tons of catalysts there.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @BeanieBabyTrade It led to deflationary collapse in the 1930s because there was no FDIC insurance, and when the roaring credit bubble burst, about a third of banks went bankrupt and depositor money was lost.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Gold is still basically following real rates.   With reflationary data coming in at a time when Treasury yields ease, gold has been catching somewhat of a bid here, after its correction since August 2020.  https://t.co/Zf1WSO75qx

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: In other words, when M2 goes up a lot, *something* is generally inflating. Either financial assets or goods/commodities.  The first box period in the 1920s ended with deflationary collapse. The second box period in the 1960s ended with inflationary pressures and rising rates.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: During periods when money supply growth goes up a lot while inflation remains low, it generally pushes up asset valuations instead (asset price inflation). Black boxes in the charts:  https://t.co/0NVf7EQJAl

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @Tail__Risk @nic__carter @CaseyJScalf I do think now BTC is big enough and followed enough that markets will price in halvings. Not the 2020 one imo.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @joonian @nic__carter @CaseyJScalf In reality, yes.   Among the quorum of current and prospective buyers, no.   For an asset as small as BTC was in 2020, they do the math once the price goes up 5x and their boss is asking why they aren't long.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @nic__carter @CaseyJScalf In other words, it's a compliment to Nic, despite disagreeing.   People who felt it was obvious and efficient, were 0.1% of the potential investors. The rest of the big money was like, "what?"  Some thoughts on EMH from years ago:   https://t.co/AAdcEghthW

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @nic__carter @CaseyJScalf Only a minority of investors focus on the long-run. Many are traders.   Bitcoin was small enough, with a short enough sample size, that the halving wasn't priced in by a quorum current+future participants, imo.   People on the bleeding edge felt it was more obvious than reality.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @nic__carter @CaseyJScalf IMO the halving wasn't priced in.   As someone who followed commodity markets for 15 years, in small and relatively underfollowed commodity markets, price moves when supply shocks actually happen, rather than when a minority of folks do the math and see that they will happen.

name: Lyn Alden

The month-over-month CPI increase (chart on the right) was also the highest in over a decade.  https://t.co/bz3YR6Y5Bt

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @JeffBooth I think it will come down to whether they keep doing large fiscal bills or not.   Seems to me that there's a political will to push it now. If they stop, though, then yes commodity/goods inflation would likely not be very persistent.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Due to growth in M2 and a change in political will for fiscal spending, I do think inflationary impacts could be relatively persistent after these easy base effect comps.   However, it's important to separate the base effect comps from the potentially more persistent outcomes.  https://t.co/yr0BOaJOnM

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Deflationists will argue that these inflationary effects are transient.   Inflationists will hype up the importance of these late-spring YoY headline numbers.   The truth will likely be somewhere between, and it won‚Äôt be until later this summer that data will be more instructive.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: There was a good article about these base effects in the WSJ yesterday by @jasonzweigwsj   It‚Äôll be important in this period to look at month-over-month or multi-year changes for various economic indicators, not just YoY.   https://t.co/Br4ZdJ6XaW

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: This holds true for all sorts of Q2 2020 vs Q2 2021 economic indicators, including GDP, corporate earnings, consumer spending, etc.   The easy comp base effects will result in some modern record year-over-year figures.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: These unusual base effects already occurred for March 2020 vs March 2021 for asset prices, since asset prices bottomed before economic indicators.   For example, the Wilshire 5000 had its best year-over-year increase ever:  https://t.co/t5N564JQrE

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: The producer price index for March is already over 4% year-over-year, and could very well hit over 7% in April or May thanks to low base effects and fiscal-driven reflation:  https://t.co/Hz5L6bo9Dk

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: In April and May, there will be various easy comps from low base effects that will make some year-over-year numbers look quite high.   Official CPI for example is likely to hit over 3% year over year:  https://t.co/ul9v2ZdpCB

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @rottenbanana101 It's the portion of government debt that is not held by government agencies.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @StephenBandy6 The larger amount of money makes more demand for the assets.   Think of it in ratio terms. Most folks won't leave assets primarily in cash. They will bid other assets up and keep a large percentage of assets in those bigger market cap assets, even though the money trades hands.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Some of my chart legends didn't update properly. Money multiplier should be rhs here (aka right axis), not lhs. The others are lhs.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: @bobbyeubank Legend error. Money multiplier is rhs axis. Positive number.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: In April/May (reported May/June), we‚Äôll get some higher year-over-year CPI prints from low base effects.   After that, broad inflation levels will partly depend on what happens with the next round of fiscal stimulus: if it passes, how big it is, what it targets, etc.  https://t.co/blluj4qvzD

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: To the extent that broad money supply goes up a lot and CPI and bond yields stay relatively low, then the money tends to pile into financial assets, since it has to go somewhere. Lately that‚Äôs what the situation has been.  https://t.co/nKfOnEd938

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: If they can do a large fiscal burst (spending without associated tax increases), and there is no big inflationary response, then the incentive exists for them to do it again. And again. And again. The only limiter would be obvious inflation.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: The deflationary capacity of the current economy is huge, due to automation, software, high debt, wealth concentration, and aging demographics.   And policymakers will be putting that deflationary force to the test.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: And that‚Äôs not a criticism of policymakers in the era. For investors, there were winners and losers in that scenario depending on what asset classes they were primarily in.   Since it was a currency devaluation, it was cash and bondholders that took the brunt of it.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: In other words, if extreme fiscal policy were not occurring in the 1940s, prices would go back to normal after their brief spike from temporary shortages.   The reason they didn‚Äôt go back to normal was because the currency itself was devalued.

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: The reason those 1940s price increases were not transient, is because behind the surface of commodity shortages there was a massive increase in the broad money supply due to fiscal spending, which was effectively monetized.  https://t.co/LdgkM9iFNr

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: However, the consumer price index never returned to baseline after those inflationary spikes. Those spikes each brought broad prices up to permanently higher levels.   From 1940-1952, the consumer price index went up 90% and stayed there forever.  https://t.co/YrztFUu17a

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Some people dismiss the 1940s inflationary period as being just transient spikes of inflation due to specific temporary shortages.   And indeed, the inflation of that era came in bursts:  https://t.co/BydXUea4BR

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Deflation proponents often point out that the money multiplier (broad money as a multiple of the monetary base) is low right now. That‚Äôs true.   However, the only other time it was this low (the 1940s), was actually quite inflationary.  https://t.co/Z074c9VySb

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: Similarly, the 2010s had a partial unwinding of a private debt bubble and a large monetary response, but limited fiscal response.   It wasn‚Äôt until the pandemic in 2020 that policymakers brought out the fiscal cannon.  https://t.co/ie4GDpHjno

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: During the 1930s, monetary policy hit the limit of what it can do against the prospect of a private debt bubble, and so it was then a massive fiscal response in the 1940s, forced by external factors (the war), that pumped inflation:  https://t.co/vASoyw7GTM

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: In terms of overall fiscal and monetary policy, including the wartime-like fiscal response that we‚Äôve seen over the past year, the 2020s so far have structural similarities to the 1940s.   Here‚Äôs the long-term debt cycle, for example:  https://t.co/x4x8g5kDso

name: Lyn Alden
tweet: The next few years are going to test how much deflationary capacity there is in the US and global economy from technology, debt, and demographics to absorb the inflationary increase in broad money.  A thread.  https://t.co/UkunAI0u5b
